controls.title: Ensure logrotate is configured
controls.description: The system includes the capability of rotating log files regularly to avoid filling up the system with logs or making the logs unmanageably large.
controls.rationale: By keeping the log files smaller and more manageable, a system administrator can easily archive these files to another system and spend less time looking through inordinately large log files.
controls.audit: Review /etc/logrotate.conf and /etc/logrotate.d/* and verify logs are rotated according to site policy.
controls.remediation: Edit /etc/logrotate.conf and /etc/logrotate.d/* to ensure logs are rotated according to site policy.
controls.references: 1. See the logrotate(8) man page for more information.

controls.title: Ensure logrotate assigns appropriate permissions
controls.description: The /etc/logrotate.conf and /etc/logrotate.d/* files control the rotation of log files.
controls.rationale: It is important to ensure that log files have the correct permissions to ensure that sensitive data is archived and protected.
controls.audit:
Run the following command to verify that create mode is set to 0640 or more restrictive:
# grep -Es '^\s*create\s+[0-7][0-7][0-7][0-7]' /etc/logrotate.conf /etc/logrotate.d/*
Verify that the mode is 0640 or more restrictive
controls.remediation: Edit /etc/logrotate.conf and /etc/logrotate.d/* to ensure that create mode is set to 0640 or more restrictive.
controls.references: 1. See the logrotate(8) man page for more information.
